content.description: Sit-start, pull onto a left crimp, and work upwards using a couple of good jugs above. Moves off the ground are probably the crux, and position of jugs provide some good movement/positioning in the upper parts. You can continue to the top after reaching the first shelf, but it's preferable to downclimb or jump down to avoid the mediocre top-out and save a hike back around to the bottom.
content.location: Immediately off the Portage Route Trail on the north side. The climb follows an arete and face just right of a spray-painted "ZK 3" (my best guess at least).

content.description: Sitting match start on a large jug with feet on a ledge to the middle-right. Move to a left crimp, adjust feet, and pull against a difficult hold around the corner to the left. Continue to a right-hand sloper and left-hand crimp above. After moving feet up, the climb finishes by matching hands on a separate boulder above.
content.location: Just east of Laminated Mantle on the north side of the Portage Route Trail, this route is on a detached boulder that resembles a face from the right angle.

content.description: Fun and easy climb. Sit-start on the right of the S-shaped crack, then work your way into the crack and climb to the top on jugs. Crux is probably the first few moves off the ground, with some good moves in the crack up above.
content.location: On the middle- to west-side of the short basalt cliffs immediately to the north of the Portage Route Trail, look for slight S-shaped crack. If you've made it to the taller volcanic flow/conglomerate cliff, you've gone too far west.

content.description: Begin with a sit-start on two jugs and a heel hook. Use crimps and side-pulls on the face and the arete on the left to work straight up, then move right once you can reach the top. The route is finished once you have both hands in the wide crack/hole that goes straight into the ledge above. An optional top-out is a little loose and not really worth the effort.
content.location: Near the beginning of the Portage Route Trail, this problem is just east of a spray-painted smurf face on the south side of the trail.

content.description: Fun sit-start with mantle and balance move to start; follow the crack for a straightforward match finish (to a point on the right).
content.location: Middle of the area, on the north side of the trail; is a big slab with distinct cracks and various etches (including a croissant).
